# 1 02-16-2007, 04:20 PM romualdfavre Registered User Join Date: Jan 2007 Posts: 12 Enter Credit Card charges in QB Im right now recording a credit card bill. It seems that it can be done in 2 ways: either by means of the function Enter Credit Card Charges, then reconciling the CC bill. Or in recording it as a normal bill. Is that right? The first way would allow entering regularly into QB the expenses of the CC and reconcile at the end. Also, for each transaction, a specific vendor can be entered. Finally, its a good way of controlling no limit exceeding. This seems hence to be some good advantages for going for this option. But doesnt it take more time proceeding this way? Wouldnt be easier to collect the CC sales receipts, and only check them when recording the CC bill? Also , for some recurrent expenses (like fuel or restaurant), I guess it doesnt make sense to record each individual gas station or fast food restaurant, can we go for a generic vendor name? Thanks in advance for sharing with me your experience in this matter. R. Favre

# 2 02-17-2007, 07:28 PM LauraD Moderator Join Date: Jun 2006 Location: Rhode Island Posts: 1,160 I totally vote for setting the credit card up as a credit card type account in QuickBooks. Enter purchases through the 'enter credit card' screen.
You can create generic vendors (Meals&ent, Gas&auto, etc) for recurrent purchases where you don't need to track the vendor name.
You need to expense the purchases anyhow, and using the cc platform gives you the most detail when you do need a report, etc. If you have your preferences set to 'auto-recall last transaction for this name', it will flow rather quickly. . .
It also posts the purchases correctly for tax purposes.
